poem:
The Smash Burger Phenomenon

In the morning paper,
a headline splatters:
flattened burgers, stacked like dreams
in the hands of cooks with spatulas
as gavels, rendering judgments
in sizzling kitchens. A new ritual
for the hungry, craving the crisp
edges of their longing,
waiting for the moment
to take a bite of what's become
our latest edible obsession.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Squash them flat, pile them high: the rise and rise of the smash burger Food trends move at incredible speed – but even so, the rise of the smash burger has been remarkable. Less than a year ago, this style – essentially, burgers rendered as wider, flatter, crispier patties, for maximum flavour – was a fairly niche concern. An enthusiastic hardcore, including Newcastle’s Meat: Stack, Danny’s Burgers in Bristol and Slap & Pickle’s mainly northern". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
